conclusion: Consider principles of gravity, collision, and deflection.
Block A is shown in motion, indicated by the red arrow.
The trajectory suggests that Block A is moving horizontally towards the right side of the image.
Gravity will pull Block A downward as it moves horizontally.
Block A will fall straight down once it reaches the table surface.
Block A is moving towards the yellow blocks on the right side of the image.
Block A is likely to collide with the topmost yellow block first.
When Block A collides with the topmost yellow block, it will exert a force on it.
Depending on the mass and velocity of Block A, the yellow block may either remain stationary or be displaced slightly.
If the yellow block remains stationary, Block A will likely come to rest on top of it.
If the yellow block is displaced, Block A may land on the adjacent yellow block or even the green surface if the displacement is significant.
Assuming the yellow blocks are relatively stable and do not move much upon impact, Block A will most likely land on top of the topmost yellow block.
If there is any deflection, it would be minimal due to the close proximity of the blocks.
Block A will collide with the topmost yellow block and will likely land on top of it.
The final landing position will be on the topmost yellow block, assuming minimal deflection and stable collision dynamics.
